channel.title: 纽约时报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: The James Webb Space Telescope, the dreams and work of a generation of astronomers, headed for an orbit around the sun on Christmas Day. Astronomers jubilantly watched the launch remotely from all over the world, many Zooming together in their pajamas. https://t.co/mQ8RMFHDY4

An Italian factory worker was dealing with a lifelong impairment that made it hard to work, but he wasn’t in a position to retire. Then his co-workers gave him 20 months’ worth of vacation days. https://t.co/KRf4DPaUN2

Individually, books are frequently useful or delightful, but it is when books are displayed en masse that they really work wonders. Covering the walls of a room and exuding the breath of generations, they nourish the senses, slay boredom and relieve stress.https://t.co/qp7nW8hpGX

High schoolers across the U.S. have reported some of the most alarming mental health declines, evidenced by depression and suicide attempts. Adolescents have failed classes critical to their futures at higher rates than in previous years. https://t.co/qAHy2ab728

“Although it’s a time of great happiness and good cheer for many, Christmas can be hard for those who have lost loved ones,” Queen Elizabeth II said in her first Christmas address since the death of her husband. “This year, especially, I understand why.” https://t.co/VBgwj8SFvT

Should birth-control pills be made available over the counter rather than requiring a prescription? This is the heart of a debate now playing out in the pharmaceutical industry and at the FDA. https://t.co/SRKQRkGgIZ

George Floyd’s murder set in motion shock waves that touched almost every aspect of American society. But on the core issues of police violence and accountability, very little has changed. https://t.co/tHx4doxW4I

The Webb telescope, the most powerful space observatory ever built, lifted off Christmas morning. It will be orbiting the sun at a point beyond the moon, a million miles from Earth, which is way out of the reach of astronaut help. https://t.co/48NIDE89He https://t.co/fP2mcfb4qM
Breaking News: The Webb telescope, the biggest space observatory ever built, launched on its million-mile journey to the morning of time. https://t.co/1BKxlAxdt6

A wealthy family in Myanmar known for its charity work has secretly helped equip the country's brutal military and evaded Western scrutiny, an investigation by The New York Times has found. https://t.co/gNCMvItaUx

ပြင်ပကမ္ဘာအတွက်ဆိုလျှင် ဗမာ-အိုင်ယာလန် ကပြားမိသားစုသည် မြန်မာနိုင်ငံပြုပြင်ပြောင်းလဲရေးကို လိုလားသော အထက်တန်းစားများအဖြစ် သိကြပါမည်။ သို့သော် ထိုမိသားစုသည် ရက်စက်ကြမ်းကြုတ်သော စစ်တပ်ကို တိတ်တဆိတ် လက်နက်တပ်ဆင်ထားသည်။ https://t.co/V9DW8BrDGz

Denzel Washington and Frances McDormand play a toxic power couple in Joel Coen’s crackling adaptation of "Macbeth." The film is an NYT Critic's Pick. "Every scene is a mini-master class in the craft of acting." https://t.co/bQV12ZRv18

South Africa’s government, buoyed by data showing that infections from the Omicron variant aren’t as severe, has dropped quarantine restrictions for all but symptomatic people. https://t.co/gMCan4W1eo

High schoolers across the U.S. have reported some of the most alarming mental health declines, evidenced by depression and suicide attempts. Adolescents have failed classes critical to their futures at higher rates than in previous years. https://t.co/oyQCKZ29By https://t.co/Q1nvy2Ebug

Hundreds of right-wing Hindu activists and monks at a conference took an oath to harm Muslims if necessary to make “a Hindu-only nation,” the most blatant and alarming example of rising anti-Muslim sentiment across India. https://t.co/uFEvcLNdqg

Peter Dinklage is happy to upend 100 years of clichés by playing the romantic lead. The four-time Emmy winner spoke to us about the new movie musical “Cyrano" and life after "Game of Thrones." https://t.co/zteRagLLQU

A Los Angeles police officer opened fire on a man who was involved in an assault at a clothing store on Thursday, and one of the shots pierced a wall, killing a 14-year-old girl in a dressing room, the police said. https://t.co/PslsmVPXXT

The Elf on a Shelf is not, several privacy organizations were careful to say, the biggest threat the world faces. But they fear he teaches children to passively accept constantly being watched by an unseen authority figure. https://t.co/tGWQAV9yqd

An Australian landowner and two companies have been hit with hundreds of animal cruelty charges after a land-clearing operation last year led to the deaths of 70 koalas, an episode that one lawmaker described as a “massacre.” https://t.co/X8s4VE52qN

Canada will compensate Indigenous people for the decades that many have lived with contaminated drinking water.
The government will also commit to spend at least 6 billion Canadian dollars to fund clean-up efforts on hundreds of Indigenous reserves. https://t.co/OfdmJ63uSg

Joan Didion, the author of "The Year of Magical Thinking," "Slouching Towards Bethlehem" and "The White Album," to name a few, died on Thursday. She was also a prolific writer for The New York Times. https://t.co/jW5jY5WYie

The flu virus, which all but disappeared in early 2020, has re-emerged in the U.S. as the Omicron variant has driven up coronavirus infections and travel is expected to increase over the holidays. https://t.co/ED6CJUz23N https://t.co/prqBj3njrm

Kimberly Potter, the former police officer who fatally shot Daunte Wright after seeming to mistake her gun for her Taser, was convicted of two counts of manslaughter on Thursday. A judge will sentence Potter at a hearing scheduled for February. https://t.co/BzgG17WVcV https://t.co/4NE4c44BaL

Joan Didion was a generation-defining writer. "She could not tire of telling her reader, telling herself, that luck runs out — perhaps because she never really believed it, not when there was more life to be lived," writes Parul Sehgal. https://t.co/huEzeSeQNx https://t.co/W31qEGrMfe

Breaking News: Kimberly Potter, the former police officer who killed Daunte Wright after drawing her gun instead of her Taser during a traffic stop, was convicted of manslaughter. https://t.co/JqKyVqPEsr
Joan Didion was a prolific writer of stylish essays, novels, screenplays and memoirs. Here is an overview of some of her works, as reviewed in The New York Times. https://t.co/YxRUvt1CLI

For half a century, Joan Didion, who died on Thursday, was the grand diagnostician of American disorder in essays of strong, unmistakable cadence. She wrote her first story at age 5, after her mother told her to stop whining and to write down her thoughts.https://t.co/2vf0igpboO
Holiday travel is happening, despite Omicron. If you want to travel responsibly, here are some strategies you can follow. https://t.co/WA0K0KeKhC https://t.co/gdpX98yRbb

Breaking News: Joan Didion has died at age 87. Her sharp dispatches on California and tough, terse novels forged a distinct new voice in American writing. https://t.co/Y7Yiv18CS9 https://t.co/flsrs0cChn

The authorities in Hong Kong removed a statue, known as the “Pillar of Shame,” that memorialized those killed in the 1989 Tiananmen massacre. The removal of the statue, a symbol of the territory’s pro-democracy movement, is the latest crackdown on dissent. https://t.co/m1mOh3Ijfa

“I’ve been targeted by public security,” Li Tiantian, an outspoken teacher in rural China, told a friend in a text message before she disappeared.
Chinese social media has echoed for days with a question: Where is Li Tiantian? https://t.co/v6Gvz7KCzi
Active, physically fit men and women are more than twice as likely to be moderate or heavy drinkers as people who are out of shape, a new study found. https://t.co/xkoLk7IZ4Y

The House committee investigating the Capitol attack wants to interview Rep. Jim Jordan, a Republican congressman from Ohio. Jordan was deeply involved in Donald Trump's effort to fight the 2020 election results. https://t.co/2CRwOgMFOj

We interviewed Carrie-Anne Moss, who played Trinity in "The Matrix," about returning to the role years later for the new sequel: "It was important to me that I let go of any construct in my mind that I needed to look like I did when I was 30." https://t.co/ysMTZKSa73
See 2021 in pictures. https://t.co/UTwdIYtBLC https://t.co/PbQL45ElOM

Tens of millions of Americans will be eligible for Pfizer's Covid pill if they get infected with the virus, though the federal government's supply will be limited at first. Pfizer’s studies indicate that it is likely to work against the Omicron variant. https://t.co/ojlatInkY9 https://t.co/MZ0dUsPxcN

Breaking News: Omicron cases seem less severe compared with previous variants, two studies suggest. But experts warned that hospitals could still be flooded because the variant is so transmissible. https://t.co/cqtd25KV1j

Under Democratic pressure, the White House extended a pause on student loan payments by 90 days. President Biden has resisted delivering on a campaign promise to wipe $10,000 per person and been reluctant to use executive action on sweeping forgiveness. https://t.co/jub3ae4P6c https://t.co/0OL2zl5gNY

The FBI set up extensive surveillance operations inside Portland’s racial justice protest movement, a New York Times investigation found. Agents stood shoulder to shoulder with activists, guiding the police toward arrests and recording clandestine video. https://t.co/nO84DCtLgZ

Breaking News: The Biden administration has extended the pause on student loan payments to May 1. They had been set to resume in February after being effectively frozen for nearly two years during the pandemic. https://t.co/RfX3TJv0BQ

Breaking News: The FDA has cleared Pfizer’s Covid pill, the first of its kind, for high-risk people 12 and over. It was found to protect against severe illness after infection. https://t.co/1JQ3XHSKD8

Breaking News: In a White House address on Tuesday, President Biden tried to calm fears of lockdowns, outlined his Omicron plan and urged more people to get vaccinated. "This is not March of 2020," he said. https://t.co/HT7l4Fg3Jd

A California man who pleaded guilty to threatening dozens of people, including members of Congress and journalists, for saying that Donald Trump had lost the 2020 election was sentenced on Monday to three years in prison. https://t.co/3yg9Gkdl10

A billionaire from Utah, Jeff Green, said he was resigning from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in an unusually high-profile rebuke of the church’s wealth and position on social issues such as LGBTQ rights and racial equality. https://t.co/0BrZbZLpsO

Gabriel Boric rose to prominence in Chile ten years ago as a student leading rallies for free quality public education. After winning the presidency on Sunday, he is poised to oversee what may be the country's biggest overhaul in decades. https://t.co/m9N0Y5qxeI

A billionaire from Utah, Jeff Green, said he was resigning from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in an unusually high-profile rebuke of the church’s wealth and position on social issues such as LGBTQ rights and racial equality. https://t.co/ubQtIvts7F
It's still too early to know exactly how, or if, symptoms of Omicron differ from Delta, experts say. Here's what we know so far. https://t.co/GNJBhfySeY https://t.co/5JckhDKZd2

Gabriel Boric was elected president of Chile on Sunday, making the 35-year-old leftist lawmaker the country's youngest leader. He'll take office as Chile, roiled by social upheaval, completes the drafting a new Constitution. https://t.co/ZRS6QPR6Bx

A box full of $50 and $100 bills, totaling $180,000, was sent to the physics department at City College of New York. An enclosed note from the mysterious donor asked the school to use the cash to fund scholarships for needy students. https://t.co/LwFKlKLJz7 https://t.co/laBQFOU07u

About 1,400 striking Kellogg workers have ratified a new contract, their union said Tuesday, ending a strike that began in early October and affected four of the company’s U.S. cereal plants. https://t.co/Z6UQaZTC3q
